title: How to Paint Scary Trees by Blowing Through a Straw

steps.headline: Prepare your work space and paper.
steps.description: Cover a table with newspapers or  plastic. Tear a piece of paper from a pad of #140 weight watercolor paper. Find an old shirt to wear as a smock over your clothes. Set out a drinking straw, a pencil, a ragged piece of natural sponge, a two inch square of cardboard, a fine line Sharpie or other black marker, an assortment of paint brushes and a set of watercolors.

steps.headline: Squeeze out half an inch of black watercolor paint into a cup or small container.
steps.description: To get the black paint the right consistency to scatter when blown through a straw, watercolor in a tube works best. Very carefully, mix three caps of water from a water bottle with the paint so it resembles the consistency of milk. Test it on a piece of scrap paper to see that it isn't diluted too much and set it aside.

steps.headline: Wet the pads of color in your paint box.
Place paper in front of you in either a horizontal or vertical orientation.
steps.description: Using pencil, divide the paper into unequal and approximate thirds. Draw the tree trunk and main branches. Add a horizon line.

steps.headline: Paint the background first.
steps.description: Keeping scenery in mind, paint on your paper directly, creating a band for the ground, one for the distant mountains or prairie and the sky. Do this only once getting plenty of color onto the paper. Let it dry.

steps.headline: Paint the trunk and the main branches of the tree.
steps.description: Using the cup of black and a large, round, pointed brush, make a tree. Work one branch at a time. On one branch, add more black paint and complete it.

steps.headline: Blow through a straw to disperse the black paint.
steps.description: Think about these as smaller, ever diminishing in size new branches and twigs. Repeat on the next branch. Add more spots of black paint as needed to give you a fine array of branches. Turn your paper to go in many directions. Continue until you are satisfied with the tree.

steps.headline: Make a pine tree using a credit card or a piece of cardboard.
steps.description: Use it as a stamping device. Touch an edge into a puddle of black paint and stamp a line of branches with it.

steps.headline: Use a piece of sponge to make some dead foliage on a branch or two.
steps.description: Wet the sponge, wring it out and touch it to a puddle of black paint. Stamp with it, creating some dead leaf clusters on some of the branches.

steps.headline: Paint a crow in flight in black paint.
steps.description: Use a small, pointed brush for this. Paint an owl on a branch. Add the silhouette of a scarecrow.

steps.headline: Make fence posts with a small brush.
steps.description: They are just short upright strokes of black. Connect them, with lines to resemble wire, with a fine line Sharpie.

steps.headline: Work on the foreground.
steps.description: Upgrade the foreground with weeds by making bold, horizontal, strokes of brown watercolor and scratching vertical lines into the wet wash with the point of a paper clip (unfolded) or the edge of a plastic credit card.

steps.headline: When your work is finished, step back and admire it.
steps.description: You will see what a frightening tree and scene you’ve made. Hang it up to give your room Halloween ambiance.
